Theory

theory.Rmd


ğŸ¯ Aim

Characterizing interactions between drugs is an area of major interest for drug
development, as exploiting synergism between drugs could allow increasing treatment efficacy using lower doses of single drugs, and avoiding antagonistic interaction is needed to maintain the therapeutic efficacy of drugs. Broadly speaking, synergism and antagonism could be defined as an increase or a reduction of the effect of a drug combination compared to the effect expected for the combination on the basis of the single agent effects.

The EDITH package enables the synergistic effects of two or three drugs to be explored, based on cell viability data obtained from combination experiments. The package is designed to analyze and visualize drug interactions and implements a widely used method for assessing drug interactions: the Bliss independence model.


ğŸ“ Bliss independence model

The Bliss independence model is a mathematical framework used to evaluate the independence (ie. the absence of any interaction effect) of two drugs when they are administered in combination. The general form of Bliss independence model is the following equation:

Ecombined=EA+EBâˆ’(EAâ‹…EB)E_{combined} = E_A + E_B - (E_A \cdot E_B) where:

  • EAE_A is the effect of drug A,
  • EBE_B is the effect of drug B,
  • EcombinedE_{combined} is the expected effect of the drug combination.

In the case of a cancer cell population, the effect will correspond to the fraction of cells killed by the drug(s). For example, if drug A kills 30% of the cells, EA=0.3E_A = 0.3 and drug B kills 40% of the cells EB=0.4E_B = 0.4. According to the Bliss independence model, the expected effect of the combination of drugs A and B would be: Ecombined=0.3+0.4âˆ’(0.3Ã—0.4)=0.58E_{combined} = 0.3 + 0.4 - (0.3 \times 0.4) = 0.58 This means that the combination of drugs A and B is expected to kill 58% of the cells if they act independently.

The Bliss equation can be recast in terms of unaffected cells as follows:

Ucombined=UAâ‹…UBU_{combined} = U_A \cdot U_B

where:

  • UAU_A is the fraction of unaffected cells by drug A (ie. viability after treatment with drug A),
  • UBU_B is the fraction of unaffected cells by drug B (ie. viability after treatment with drug B),
  • UcombinedU_{combined} is the expected fraction of unaffected cells by the drug combination.

For example, if drug A leaves 70% of the cells unaffected, UA=0.7U_A = 0.7 and drug B leaves 60% of the cells unaffected UB=0.6U_B = 0.6. According to the Bliss independence model, the expected fraction of unaffected cells by the combination of drugs A and B would be:

Ucombined=0.7Ã—0.6=0.42U_{combined} = 0.7 \times 0.6 = 0.42 This means that the combination of drugs A and B is expected to leave 42% of the cells unaffected if they act independently.

The generalized form of the Bliss equation for a combination of n drugs is:

Ucombined=âˆi=1nUiU_{combined} = \prod_{i=1}^n U_i

where:

  • i=1,...,ni = 1, ..., n indexes the drugs in the combination,
  • UiU_i is the fraction of unaffected cells by drug ii.

ğŸš¨ Important: The values in the input matrix must correspond to the percentage of living cells.

ğŸ” Evaluation of drug interactions

To evaluate the interaction between drugs, the observed effect of the drug combination is compared to the expected effect calculated using the Bliss independence model. This is simply done by subtracting the observed effect from the expected effect:

Interaction=Uexpectedâˆ’UobservedInteraction = U_{expected} - U_{observed}


ğŸ§© Interpretation:

The interaction can be classified into three categories based on this comparison:

  • âš¡ Synergy:More cells killed than expected â†’ positive interaction effect (Uexpectedâˆ’UobservedU_{expected} - U_{observed})
  • âš–ï¸ Additivity: As many cells killed as expected â†’ no interaction effect (Uexpectedâ‰ˆUobservedU_{expected} â‰ˆ U_{observed})
  • âš”ï¸ Antagonism: Less cells killed than expected â†’ negative interaction effect (Uexpected>UobservedU_{expected} > U_{observed})


ğŸ‘€ ï¸Visual example

To illustrate the interaction estimation, consider the following example with two drugs, A and B:


ğŸ§® Quantification of drug interactions

In addition to this point-bypoint estimation, different measures can be used to quantify drug interactions. In the EDITH package, we implement three different indexes: the additive index, the combination index and the efficacy index.

ğŸš¨ Important: These indexes can be used if and only if the dilution factor is fixed between all the dose levels for each drug used in the cytotocixity assay.

ğŸš¨ Important: These indexes can be used to compared different experiments if and only if the same drug concentration ranges and the same dilution factors are used in all experiments.


ğŸŒŸ Combination index

According to the approach proposed by LehÃ¡r (LehÃ¡r et al., 2007, 2008, 2009), the combination index, is calculated as follows:

CI=lnfAâ‹…lnfBâ‹…âˆ‘A,B(Uexpectedâˆ’Uobserved)CI = \ln f_A \cdot \ln f_B \cdot \sum_{A,B} (U_{expected} - U_{observed})

where:

  • fAf_A and fBf_B are the dilution factors used in the cytotocixity assay for drugs A and B respectively,
  • UobservedU_{observed} and UexpectedU_{expected} are the matrices of the survival percentage for the experimental data and for the corresponding Bliss independence data, respectively.

The generalized form of the equation for a combination of nn drugs is:

CI=âˆi=1nlnfiâ‹…âˆ‘i=1n(Uexpectedâˆ’Uobserved)iCI = \prod_{i=1}^n \ln f_i \cdot \sum_{i=1}^n (U_{expected} - U_{observed})_i

where:

  • fif_i is the dilution factor used in the cytotoxicity assay for drug ii,
  • UobservedU_{observed} and UexpectedU_{expected} are the matrices of the survival percentage for the experimental data and for the corresponding Bliss independence data, respectively.

ğŸ§© Interpretation: The higher the combination index, the more synergistic the drugs are.


ğŸŒŸ Efficacy index

An efficacy index is calculated as follow:

EI=lnfAâ‹…lnfBâ‹…âˆ‘A,B(100âˆ’Uobserved)EI = \ln f_A \cdot \ln f_B \cdot \sum_{A,B} (100 - U_{observed})

where:

  • fAf_A and fBf_B are the dilution factors used in the cytotocixity assay for drugs A and B respectively,
  • UobservedU_{observed} is the matrix of the survival percentage for the experimental data.

The generalized form of the equation for a combination of nn drugs is:

EI=âˆi=1nlnfiâ‹…âˆ‘i=1n(100âˆ’Uobserved)iEI = \prod_{i=1}^n \ln f_i \cdot \sum_{i=1}^n (100 - U_{observed})_i

where:

  • fif_i is the dilution factor used in the cytotoxicity assay for drug ii,
  • UobservedU_{observed} is the matrix of the survival percentage for the experimental data.

ğŸ§© Interpretation: The higher the efficacy index, the more lethal the drugs are.


ğŸŒŸ Additivity index

An additivity index is calculated as follow:

AI=lnfAâ‹…lnfBâ‹…âˆ‘A,B(100âˆ’Uexpected)AI = \ln f_A \cdot \ln f_B \cdot \sum_{A,B} (100 - U_{expected})

where:

  • fAf_A and fBf_B are the dilution factors used in the cytotocixity assay for drugs A and B respectively,
  • UexpectedU_{expected} is the matrix of the survival percentage for the corresponding Bliss independence data.

The generalized form of the equation for a combination of nn drugs is:

AI=âˆi=1nlnfiâ‹…âˆ‘i=1n(100âˆ’Uexpected)iAI = \prod_{i=1}^n \ln f_i \cdot \sum_{i=1}^n (100 - U_{expected})_i

where:

  • fif_i is the dilution factor used in the cytotoxicity assay for drug ii,
  • UexpectedU_{expected} is the matrix of the survival percentage for the corresponding Bliss independence data.

ğŸ§© Interpretation: The higher the additivity index, the more lethal the drugs are supposed to be according to the Bliss independance model.
